description.narrative: The Stand Up for SRHR Program is designed to increase enjoyment of sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) by the most marginalized and vulnerable right-holders, particularly adolescent girls (15-19 years) and young women (20-24 years) in selected districts of Uganda, Mozambique and Sudan. The Program addresses key gender inequality and human rights issues, such as harmful social norms, traditional practices, and taboos regarding gender and sexuality, lack of adequate information on or access tocomprehensive SRH services, lack of decision-making power by adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) regarding their health and sexuality as well as limited capacity of women’s rights organizations (WROs) and youth-led organizations (YLOs) to effectivelyadvocate for SRHR in their communities. OPHENTA – Mozambican Association of Women and Support for Girls is a feminist organization created in 2017 with a mission of advocate and promote gender equality, social justice, financial autonomy, human rights-sensitive policies with a focus on womenand girls. Since its inception the women’s rights organization has accumulated work experience in participation of women in decision-making processes, preventing and combating gender-based violence, promotion women's and Girls sexual and reproductive health and rights, promotion the human rights of women and girls, lobbying and advocacy through dissemination knowledge, and promotion gender based violence (GBV) prevention in community and organizing community dialogueswith religious and traditional leaders on sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) prevention and sexual and reproductive health and rights. In this program the organization will conduct dialogues among community influencers and champions, including indigenous, religious and traditional leaders on sexual and gender based violence prevention and sexual and reproductive health and rights; Conduct gender-sensitive training for men, particularly community leaders and norm setters, on male responsibility insupporting sexual and reproductive health and rights and on women's rights; Map sexual and reproductive health and gender based violence services available at different levels; Link adolescent girls and young women to sexual and reproductive health and sexual and gender based violence services; Conduct meetings with education officials/school councils on effective mechanisms to provide comprehensive SRHR; Develop SRH educational materials to use in schools; Establish youth Friendly Spaces (corners) in community and/or selected secondary schools.

participating-org.narrative: Associação M de Mulheres e a Rapari Associação M de Mulheres e a Rapari

The Mozambican Association of Women and Support for Girls - OPHENTA is an association of private law, endowed with legal personality and with social responsibility and non-profit. It was constituted in 2016, with about 10 members. The association is based in the city of Nampula, where it will be represented in a first phase and later in the districts of Rapale and Ribaué in the province of Nampula, through local women's clubs functioning as focal points of activities. Its mission is to advocate and promote gender equality, social justice, economic and anti-violence, influencing decisions in governance processes and in the formulation and implementation of human rights sensitive policies with a focus on women and girls. Its vision is to strengthen civilsociety organizations, to promote community-based initiatives to stimulate the empowerment of women and girls, to know their basic rights and duties in the development of their communities, as an indispensable condition for influencing decision-making inthe processes of local governance and in the formulation and implementation of sensitive policies focused on the human rights of women and girls. Ophenta conducts its activities in the neighborhoods of Namicopo and military district. Thematic intervention areas: 1. Participation of women and girls in decision-making processes; 2. Combating violence against women and girls; 3. Participation of women and girls in economic development(access to and control of resources).
